feed_name: Roger Wong - Design, UX, AI, Technology
title: Thoughts and Observations Regarding Apple Creator Studio
content:
When I worked at LEVEL Studios (which became Rosetta) in the early 2010s, we had a whole group dedicated to icon design. It was small but incredibly talented and led by Jon Delman, a master of this craft. And yes, Jon and team designed icons for Apple.

Those glory days are long gone and the icons coming out of Cupertino these days are pedestrian, to put it gently. The best observation about Apple's icon decline comes from Héliographe, via John Gruber:

If you put the Apple icons in reverse it looks like the portfolio of someone getting really really good at icon design.

Posted by @heliographe.studio on Threads

Seven Pages icons from newest to oldest, each one more artistically interesting than the last. The original is exquisite. The current one is a squircle with a pen on it.

This is even more cringe-inducing when you keep in mind something Gruber recalls from a product briefing with Jony Ive years ago:

Apple didn't change things just for the sake of changing them. That Apple was insistent on only changing things if the change made things better. And that this was difficult, at times, because the urge to do something that looks new and different is strong, especially in tech.

Apple's hardware team still operates this way. An M5 MacBook Pro looks like an M1 MacBook Pro. An Apple Watch Series 11 is hard to distinguish from a Series 0. These designs don't change because they're excellent.

The software team lost that discipline somewhere. Gruber again:

I know a lot of talented UI designers and a lot of insightful UI critics. All of them agree that MacOS's UI has gotten drastically worse over the last 10 years, in ways that seem so obviously worse that it boggles the mind how it happened.

The icons are just the most visible symptom. The confidence to not change something—to trust that the current design is still the best design—requires knowing the difference between familiarity and complacency. Somewhere along the way, Apple's software designers stopped being able to tell.

Read the full article →

title: An Interview with Kalshi CEO Tarek Monsour About Prediction Markets
content:
An interview with Kalshi co-founder and CEO Tarek Monsour about the value of prediction markets.

Listen to this Update in your podcast player

Good morning,

This Stratechery Interview is another installment of the Stratechery Founder series; as a reminder, one of the challenges in covering startups is the lack of available data. My solution is to go in the opposite direction and interview founders directly, letting them give their subjective overview of their companies, while pressing them on their business model, background, and long-term potential.

Today’s Interview is with Kalshi co-founder and CEO Tarek Mansour. Kalshi is a prediction market, where you can bet on future events happening. Kalshi came to prominence in the 2024 election where it hosted a huge amount of activity on the Presidential election outcome, and proved to be more accurate than polls. Kalshi’s markets, however, go far beyond politics, covering everything from inflation data to sports outcomes. Kalshi itself is unique in that it is the only prediction market that has been approved for operations in the United States.

In this interview we discuss Mansour’s background in math and finance, and why the 2016 election helped convince him of the need for prediction markets. We talk about the Kalshi origin story, it’s path to being regulated, and how the company almost died under the previous administration. We then talk about the challenge of building new markets, and the balance between retail investors and market-making ones. We also discuss how sports has come to dominate Kalshi’s revenue, why Kalshi believes that new knowledge from insider trading isn’t worth destroying people’s sense of fairness about a new kind of financial company, and why prediction markets are essential for preserving market access to the general population.

As a reminder, all Stratechery content, including interviews, is available as a podcast; click the link at the top of this email to add Stratechery to your podcast player.

On to the Interview:

An Interview with Kalshi CEO Tarek Monsour About Prediction Markets

This interview is lightly edited for clarity.

Topics:

Background | The Kalshi Origin Story | Prediction Market Regulation | Creating Markets | Sports | Fees and Insider Trading | Social Value

Background

Tarek Mansour, welcome to Stratechery.

Tarek Mansour: Thanks for having me, Ben. I’m very excited.

I’m very excited about this conversation as well, but before I start talking about Kalshi and prediction markets, I like to hear about people’s background and you have a very interesting one, so I want to hear the Tarek’s life story. Let’s start with where you grew up, which was somewhere else in the world than where you are at right now.

TM: I was born in California actually, in Bakersfield.

Oh, interesting.

TM: My dad was studying for med school and then they didn’t really love living in Bakersfield, so they moved back to Lebanon when I was pretty young, so they’re both Lebanese, and I grew up in Lebanon. It was a very different upbringing, it was definitely not what you’re used to or not a typical upbringing in the US.

A few things shaped me, I would say a bit, but I’ve always had a little bit of a obsessive brain, I have a bit of OCD and tend to be obsessed with things and so that was one part of it and that led me to first being very obsessed with math and getting into finance and later on downline get to Kalshi.

Even as a kid, was math your real obsession?

TM: Yeah, I was always very, very into math. It was a bit of a refuge from everything else. When I was very, very young, I wasn’t super social and I think my identity started revolving around math and being the best at math, and that was kind of my whole thing and I loved it. I really, really love math.

The other kind of pillar is Lebanon is a very, you can call it a dynamic country. There’s no default states, always changing, and the political environment is very, very rough, and then also had a few wars and a series of bombings, so there was kind of this constant state of instability that I think both of those things led me to like, “Okay, I have to go back to the US”, and my mom was also very much on board.

I grew up with a single mom and it was kind of like, you have to go back to US because that’s where you can make a future for yourself and do something. And I was obsessed with math, I was like, “Okay, what is the best place to go?”, and at the time I convinced myself this was MIT, so I spent five years figuring out how to get into MIT and I got there, which was exciting.

When you got to MIT, you were just going to study math? Did you know what you wanted to do?

TM: Yeah, it was like, “I like math, what are most of the smart math people doing?”, and it was computer science, so I did computer science and math, I did both, and I loved it. I think MIT was sort of widening of aperture, I went from a place where not a lot of people cared really about math or anything really, to a place where I was kind of average, a lot of people were incredibly good in talent in what they were doing.

How did you handle that? How did you handle being average at math?

TM: It was pretty exciting, honestly. I kind of liked it because I’m a very competitive person in general and so you meet people that, just their brain power was — it was really kind of elegant, it was beautiful to see and they could just think about things with the speed and with criticality of thinking that was just really impressive. So it pushed me to get better. As a very competitive person here, I want to get close and hang out with these people and try to learn from them and that has, I’d say, accelerated my trajectory quite a bit. I think that MIT can really push somebody if you want to push yourself.

Do they push you in a certain direction like, “I need to find a specific area that I’m particularly good at where it’s as easy for me as pure math is for these folks”, or was there a period of, “I’m going to overcome this, I’m going to be amazing”? I just remember, I thought I was good at math in high school and then I went to college and it became very clear that I was not that good relatively speaking to some people for whom it was effortless, and at MIT and you’re studying math, it’s like a whole other ballgame. You were definitely one of the people that would have showed me this isn’t what it is, but I had a view in my head, “Math was difficult, so it’s super important”, and I had to figure out actually things that are super easy for me is actually stuff that I’m good at, that’s why it’s easy, and I need to lean into that. Was there an aspect of that process for you or you’re just like, heads down, “I’m going to be awesome at math”, and that’s what it is?

TM: It was more the latter, it was more like, “Let me just figure out how far I can get in kind of a variety of different directions”. This is the beauty of it, you just get in and you get lost and there’s different interests and people have all sorts of interests about a variety of different things, and you just wander around a little bit and try to do everything at once and then you have to pare back a little bit because it’s too much.

But no, it was more like, “Let me see how far I can push myself”, just for the sake of it. There wasn’t sort of a specific end goal or intent it was more like, “Can I do it?” — it’s proving to yourself that you can do something. And it was some theoretical math, then it was some applied, there was some computer science, some algorithms, so there was kind of a large diversity of things, but then some patterns started emerging. I realized I really like things around probability and information theory, everything around how you can capture beliefs in a system or how can you move information from one place to the other and I realized that this is kind of an area and a region that I really like.

Was there a specific precipitating event where you realized, “Oh, this is actually really powerful and interesting”?

TM: It was a mix of things, but I did take a specific class actually, it was called Information Inference at MIT. What I loved is the professor, Greg [Wornell], would have a bunch of lectures and each lecture has a topic, and maybe model capacity is one topic, or inference is another, and then he would start the lecture with 15 minutes of history of what were the sort of early innings of usage of this concept and a lot of it was actually revolved around navigation, so how sailors would figure out where they were in the ocean via inference, and it was actually a lot of their modeling of where they were was actually probabilistic in nature. They weren’t actually quite sure of where they were in the ocean, but it was fascinating, it was really cool, and the class was very hard, so it was also a big challenge.

I think challenging things for competitive people, you tend to like them even more because they’re interesting and they engage you and maybe as an aside, I’m a strong believer of when you ask someone like, “Hey, what’d you do this weekend?”, or like, “Did you have a great weekend?”, they’re like, “Oh, I had a really, really great weekend, I really enjoyed it”. It’s like, “Oh, what did you do?”, it’s like, “I went on a hike, it was exhausting”, and there’s like, “Oh, what did you do later?”, “I did X and my legs are hurting”, and then you realize actually most activities that people think about enjoying are actually things that are sometimes painful, tiring, all of that, but it’s all about being engaged with the activity, it’s actually challenging you. So that was very much the case there, and then I think as someone who likes math and probability, start spending time in finance naturally.

The Kalshi Origin Story

I was going to ask you, when did the finance angle come in?

TM: It’s like, “Where are some of the smart people in math and what are the problems they’re excited about?” and, “Where can you do a lot of probability and this type of applied math?”, and it is in finance. That’s one of the really common applications, so I started spending time doing internships and all of that in finance.

One of the places that I — well, I first started at Goldman and it was really interesting. First, I did structured credit, so high yield bonds, that was cool, then I did equity derivatives and specifically equity exotics, that was really cool. I really liked that because there the vast majority of demand in the desk was essentially this notion of, “I’m trying to price something that may happen in the world that may impact me”, it was 2016, so there was two big, massive events. It was Brexit and then the election, the first Trump election and this was sort of when the early innings of Kalshi starts forming because the vast majority of the demand was basically, I want to get exposure to Brexit or hedge against Brexit and I want to get exposure to Trump and hedge against Trump.

And, “Why could you just put a contract on it directly?”

TM: It was just so obvious, and I didn’t even think about it immediately. It was first, “Okay, how do we do it?”, and then we would create bundles, so the specific trade that was a Trump trade that summer that we sold loads of was essentially you create a calendar spread, so it’s two options, one that expires right before the election and one that expires right after, it’s like the latest option that expires before the election and the earliest option that expires after and you go long one and short one so that you have an effective short on the S&P, that was a Trump trade, “The S&P will go down in that week if Trump wins” — consensus, there was no question about that consensus, we didn’t even get a question from the people buying it. It’s like, “Well, what if he wins and it goes up?”, it wasn’t even in question.

I can’t remember, did it go up or did it go down?

TM: It rallied really hard.

That’s what I thought, I was trying to remember. Actually, it’s amazing how long ago that’s been now. That’s funny, you sold all these contracts and then they all went sideways.

TM: It rallied incredibly hard. And so people are right about their prediction, but they lost money and so you had this, you kind of sit there and you’re like, “Well, this is a bad product, it’s a really bad product for what the intended use case is”.

People went to your desk and said, “I think Trump will win”, and you sold them a financial product that actually punished them.

TM: And if you think about it, why would it be a great product? I mean, there is obviously, there’s a huge basis for this, there’s a huge delta that you’re basically taking on here because really what you’re trying to price is the reaction of the markets, traditional markets, bonds or equities or whatever to the event.

You’re introducing so many more variables to whether it comes through.

TM: Exactly. It’s pretty much close to actually orthogonal, really, you don’t know what’s priced in and what’s not, and it’s really hard.

I think about it like a car backing up with a trailer.

TM: Exactly.

Sometimes you turn the wheel one way and it goes one way and sometimes it goes another, there’s a few things going on there.

TM: Exactly, that’s exactly it. You buy stock option before earnings because you think earnings are going to go well, you buy a call, then they go well, but actually it was already priced in that they were going to go well, so actually the stock goes down, and so it is actually orthogonal, it really is, it is a separate dimension that needs a separate instrument to get that exposure or hedge that exposure.

And there are separate other things which is like, and the idea that it was traded over the counter, something that common and mainstream, like an election or Brexit happening, and Brexit impacted everybody, was being traded as a bilateral instrument. It’s just you go to one party, which is the bank, and the bank prices it, and there’s no other competitive dynamic or transparent bank to discover the price, to discover the thing itself, it’s a little bit like the analogy, it’s like how a lot of this stuff, a lot of financial market started. But imagine today if we were to worry about — if you want to buy Tesla or Apple stock, there’s just one price here, it’s just like one bank that says this is the price.

Well, it’s like an IPO, right? The complaints people have with IPOs is you’re trying to price versus a direct listing where the market discovery kicks in right away. If you’re trying to price an IPO, usually it’s always way too low as everyone will complain about in part because you’re dealing with these other dynamics. You want demand, you want long-term investors, and you end up selling a bundle when people just want the one thing and the bundle kind of screws up the one thing.

TM: Exactly, and I think also the bank needs to make a lot of money.

There’s conflict of interest.

TM: Sort of, also the embedded spread, there’s a big spread that is embedded into the instrument and today, just for a rough sense, on prediction markets right now, you have one cent spread on most things. It’s like things trade 55, 56%, and you can buy 55, sell 56. At the banks, you would see things sometimes at 40% spreads. The bank, if you back imply whatever we’re pricing this thing at, it was huge, so we were charging a lot.

This was kind of the idea of you have a financial market to price companies, you have one for traditional commodities that started in the early 19th century with grain futures, and then it became commodity futures and metals. Then you got one for intangible commodities. I bucket it as interest rates, credit, currencies.

What if the next generation of financial markets is you build one for pricing events of economic and or social importance? And that was really exciting because one, I think the TAM could be much larger because a larger number of people would care, people care about economics, they care about politics, weather, sports, and so on and that set is bigger than the percentage of people that care about how IBM is going to perform next quarter.

Then the second thing is, if you believe in markets, I think what you really believe, and we can talk a little bit about this, but you’re believing that there is a pretty good mechanism, an efficient mechanism to bring out information from a system, bring information out in the open and then aggregating it pretty well, it weighs beliefs pretty well. And in this case, you’re bringing out information about questions about our future and so I got really excited about this idea and it started, I don’t know if you ever read [Friedrich] Hayek back a hundred years ago.

That’s what I was just going to ask about, you started at Kalshi in 2018, you’re thinking about this in the mid 2010s, so the idea of a prediction market was not new, but what was it about that time period that was suddenly starting to make it seem viable, this is something that could actually be done?

TM: And I think it’s worth here maybe just recapping the history real quick if you’re up for it.

Please do.

TM: There’s a few things that are relevant. First, there was Hayek who talked a bit about this kind of idea of a knowledge problem, which is basically a lot of the ways that we make decisions is in a centralized fashion, because that’s normal, like a CEO and a board running a company or like a government running an entire country. But there’s a problem, this kind of economic problem around resource allocation, which is that knowledge is often very dispersed, it’s not actually centralized the way that we think it’s centralized, it’s in local places, sometimes really hard to find how are you going—

And it’s all in pieces too, right?

TM: Exactly.

There’s no central, all the knowledge is there. It’s all the knowledge is dispersed across thousands of actors.

TM: Exactly. It’s actually kind of like four things. It’s very localized, so dispersed locally. It’s fragmented, so sometimes actually you have to have bend-

It’s the blind men feeling the elephant.

TM: Exactly, so you have to put the two pieces together from different places. Third, which makes it even more complicated, it’s dynamic, it’s not static in nature, so it’s actually changing over time, so you have to have a mechanism to pull it consistently, continuously. And then last, sometimes it’s kind of hidden, you may not even be able to know where it is, people may just not want to tell you that they have that information.

And so Hayek starts thinking about this idea that knowledge is decentralized and the best way to aggregate it is prices, like prices of things, that’s the closest aggregator of knowledge that we have today, and then it took basically, I think it was something like 40 years or 45 years after that for the first sort of prediction market to emerge, which is the Iowa Electronic Markets. I don’t know if you’ve ever heard of it.

I have not. No, I haven’t.

TM: Iowa University, very small, $100 per trader, few hundred traders, and they started with US elections and macro events. It was like a research university experiment and it was super non-liquid, very low capital, and it worked really well, it was overperforming the polls, so that was the first instance of a prediction market.

What time period is this?

TM: That was 1990s, 1985.

Okay.

TM: And it wasn’t the exact phrase because before that there were people that would take odds on elections, and the New York Times used to report on the odds because they were more accurate than polls. That was before the Great Depression, so that worked really well. And then you had in the 2000s, a bunch of companies like Google, Microsoft, HP did some internal versions of prediction markets that worked quite well, “How well is the launch going to go?”, and there there was a little bit of a weird thing there because there was a bit of a conflict of interest because the prediction markets may say things that leadership doesn’t like to hear.

Right.

TM: So that’s why they weren’t very free in that nature, so that was a problem. And I think to me, it’s like the biggest, I would say there was two big inflections.

The one inflection in 2015 was [Philip] Tetlock and the book Superforecasting and I think what it gave us is basically it was a little bit of a framework and scientific framework around, “Let’s measure if these markets work and how they work” and how judgment and belief get circulated in these systems. What he’s found is at the end of the day, actually a group of intellectually curious people will outperform experts any given day if you put them in a room, and so they were like, that have triggered things like Augur and some crypto prediction markets to start.

The second big thing I think was like, honestly, I think we were willing to take the four or five years to get it regulated to do it right.

Prediction Market Regulation

Well, so let’s talk about this. So you start Kalshi in 2018, there are other folks starting around the same time, they go offshore. And as a US citizen, you’re not supposed to bet on them. You guys decide, I think Coinbase is maybe a good analogy for your approach, which is we’re going to jump through all the hoops, convince all the relevant folks so that we can operate in the US. Is that sort of a good summary of what you decide your approach is going to be?

TM: Yeah. I think we’re like, “Okay, we’re going to do this company, we’re very excited”, and by the way, that was 2016, we decided to start two-years-and-a-half years later, end of 2018.

Yep.

TM: So one of my co-founders spent time at Bridgewater and we both spent time at Citadel and it was the same sort of thing that I just described, we’d seen the same thing, they were like, “I think there’s clearly demand, it’s also very useful if we could build this”. Then yeah, what we defined in the early days were like, “What is the thing that hasn’t let these markets really thrive?” — it was the lack of a proper regulatory framework, it was the lack of clear legality.

And why is that important?

TM: Yeah, that’s a great question. So I think, look, I would look at it from two perspectives, I think one is maybe pragmatic and one is a little bit more philosophical. The pragmatic version of this is essentially, I think in financial services and healthcare, regulation is uniquely important because when things go wrong, people get hurt in bad ways. Obviously it’s your health, but also money. People really care about their money and their wealth and that they earned and they’ve worked very hard to earn and if you do something wrong with that, it’s pretty bad, and usually that kills a company. So this idea of, “Move fast and break things”, you could move fast, but try not to break things or really avoid breaking things at all costs because you’re handling people’s money or health and so there was a little bit of — I think we did not want to build a company that has a curse of scale, that the bigger it gets, the more risky it is. Actually having regulatory buy-in with decades of regulatory experience around us would help actually pressure test the company to make sure we can withstand the test of time, the test of large scale and so on and so forth.

The philosophical one is more like, “What do you want to build at the end of the day?”, there’s many ways to be successful and achieve scale and make money. We just weren’t interested in building some sort of offshore semi-regulated, not regulated site. What we’re really excited about is, could we make this a real financial asset? Could this be the next generation New York Stock Exchange? And that was really what we wanted to build. I don’t think you can build that without real buy-in from regulators, real buy-in from mainstream brokers, institutions, like real legitimacy and so we’re just much more excited about doing that. We were like, we’re going to take however long it takes to make it regulated because we really care about this existing in the world.

Was this clear to you that this would be a big differentiator for you as well? Has it proven to be a differentiator or was that you sort of got that by accident?

TM: I don’t know, it’s interesting. In some ways for us, we made the decision independent of business success. So it wasn’t like, “Oh, we think this is going to be the correct business strategy necessarily, and that’s why we’re going to do it”, it was more like we just felt like taking this type of risk is unhealthy, it’s not right, and I think not just for us personally, it’s more like if you’re building it and you’re handling customers — at the end of day, we’re 22 years old. We want to go talk to regulators and ask them what are the things that they’re worried about and let’s figure out how to resolve them and see how we can basically get it through.

And then yes, it ended up being a huge differentiator because I think today, Kalshi is, I would say the more trusted one, we’re more mainstream, you can access us without any weird VPN or anything like that. But it wasn’t by design, it was more like we made the decision that we’re going to be a regulatory-first company because we’re in financial services.

Was there a pushback from investors about this? “This regulatory path is too difficult”, or was that actually an allure?

TM: We were so clear and dogmatic about that belief that I think I wouldn’t know basically.

Yeah, you self-selected your investors.

TM: Yeah, we self-selected investors. And even if some of them may have felt like, “Hey, you should maybe stop”, because they waited for four or five years, it’s a long time.

Yep.

TM: So I’m sure some of them thought, “Okay, what are these guys doing? They’re just waiting for this Hail Mary”, but I think it’s a little bit one of those things that you’re not going to touch that subject with someone who’s so dogmatic about it, so I don’t think no one’s brought it up is what I could say.

So you get approval in November 2020. Did you know that was coming for a while or was it suddenly like a bolt from the sky? What was the feeling when you finally are able to start operating?

TM: It was a really great feeling. We were waiting for it for two years and honestly, those two years were really difficult because it was truly 12, 14 hours a day of just regulation, no product building, nothing, just working, all the things around market integrity, customer protection, all this stuff that we need to lay down.

It was amazing because we also got a bipartisan approval, it was a five-zero vote to legalize Kalshi. But what we didn’t know is that — so we got the approval at the end of 2020, what we didn’t know is that the last administration come 2021 was going to try to throttle prediction markets at all costs, a bit like what happened with crypto. Very similar.

Yeah. So because it was bipartisan, you sort of didn’t expect that, you didn’t see that coming?

TM: We didn’t see that coming.

You needed a prediction market about how the administration was going to handle it!

TM: It was tough because we were finally, “Okay, we can launch now”, but then the way that these things go is that you can start, it’s like a death by a thousand paper cuts. “Oh, you cannot launch because of this”, and then it goes on and on and on forever basically, and so that was a very, very difficult period, very, very difficult because you thought you were across the finish line, but now actually everything is going to be unwound and undone and it was really difficult.

Concretely what was happening is essentially if we were going to do this broad prediction markets about a variety of different things, now it’s like, “Oh, you can only list four markets and nothing else”, and it’s going to be about inflation next quarter, which is very useful and interesting and Fed interest rates, but that’s not enough to build a platform and it really wasn’t. There’s also other products for Fed interest rates, for example, so we were in this very difficult position and that went on for years.

What did you perceive was the opposition? Was this just a fundamental mistrust of markets, like top down, “We get to decide what is bet on, what isn’t?”, where do you think this came from?

TM: I think the opposition was actually broader than just prediction markets, it was also to crypto, also to dream new — and even some traditional financial markets that were trying to do new things or introduce new things. And you see it, the novelty is not just coming from the prediction markets to the crypto companies, they’re coming from NASDAQ, they’re coming from CME. Those big legacy companies are also introducing a lot more novelty in the last year or so, so they were also facing similar things, but they had a prior business before that, whereas we didn’t.

Right.

TM: We were too small still where if you get stomped on and blocked, you just cannot really breathe, you cannot do anything. Whereas at a big company, you’re still fine, you can water your plants and wait for next administration to raise new plans. But it was primarily, I think there was a blanket sort of, “We don’t want innovation in financial services, financial services are mostly risks and they endanger people”, and there was a little bit of a view that it’s like retail. Trading in the stock market is gambling and it’s a way to kind of rip off customers and so on and so forth and that view was predominant.

So it’s like, why do anything new with that? It’s already bad, it’s a bad thing, so why even let it go beyond? If that’s the view that you have about the stock market, imagine the view that you have about prediction markets. And look, to be clear, and what we always said, I think all financial markets have risks, it’s like the idea to come and say, “Hey, let the innovation loose and free for all usually leads to bad outcomes”, you need proper regulation, you need proper standards, you need proper frameworks around customer protections, and you need to figure out fair rules when people are participating.

But you also need a shred of appreciation for markets actually being useful.

TM: Yes, exactly, you also need to love markets, you need to believe that markets are actually a force for good, whether it’s the stock market, which is about resource allocation and derivatives market which is about risk transfer and risk pricing and I think that lacked and I think the balance between the two is critical.

I think as a company, I really feel like we tow that balance pretty well, we believe in both, we strongly believe in the power of markets, e also strongly believe in regulation and I think we put our money where our mouth is. We spent four years getting regulated upfront, but that was really the broad and then that gets to specific arguments, maybe there could be insider trading in these markets — well, there’s insider trading in all markets, that’s not a reason to carpet ban an entire market.

I think this is the broader point, is if you’re dealing with people, it’s hard to battle their reasons when the core motivation is they just don’t see any inherent value in markets and if you’re a market maker, it’s a losing game. What are you going to do? There’s going to be a million objections. But just to get to that market maker bit, you said something about, “They said there could be four markets”, and you said that’s not enough to build a platform.

TM: Yeah.

Creating Markets

Walk me through what is necessary to build a platform. Why do you need a lot of markets? What are the sort of factors that go into this, to your point to make something new from scratch, to not have something that’s in addition to CME [Chicago Mercantile Exchange] or to the NASDAQ or whatever it might be? Just what are the dynamics of creating a market?

TM: Yeah, I think that’s a great question and maybe in a bit, we’ll talk also about the election market that ended up helping us satisfy all the dynamics that were required to build the market.

But I think financial markets, if we take a step back, they’re a form of marketplace. You have a little bit of a supply and demand dynamic. Now, the supply and demand could be fungible in this case, someone who’s supplying liquidity is acting as a “maker” can also be a taker at times and vice versa. And in financial markets, the difficulty is that you also have a virtual cycle and the marketplace is working and you have a vicious cycle and the marketplace is not working, but I think it’s a bit more pointed, it’s a bit more difficult.

At the end of the day, if you’re an Airbnb or DoorDash, you can line up some of the supply, pay them a little bit of extra time, and then as you build up the demand and then you can get the marketplace rolling. Here, it’s really hard to pay either side enough to get them to stick for long enough till the whole thing works, you truly need them to come synchronously at the same time.**

Yep. It’s the purest form of a two-sided market and you need both sides.

TM: It’s the purest form, it’s the most extreme form. But on top of that, what makes it even more difficult in our business is that you have regulation. So you have national, like a lot of it, like bank level regulation, so you have a natural throttle.

Yep.

TM: You have to also get all of that and enough momentum to get the plane off the ground, but there’s all these different weights and obstacles and it makes it really hard to maneuver the plane.

Huge amount of motivation on the market participants to sort of overcome all those hurdles.

TM: Yes, huge amount of motivation to overcome all of that and you need kind of like a very long slog to get regulated first before you even start smelling product market fit or even have a shot at the product market fit, and so what you’ve seen is that there hasn’t been much competition. The derivatives industry was CME, which is really the Chicago Board of Trade and then CME and Chicago Trade got started in 1848, so it’s a long time. And then you have ICE [Intercontinental Exchange], which has come from outside, they started in spot energy markets and then they came into derivatives, and that was started in 90s, but those are really the only two companies with meaningful scale. And anything else hasn’t really gotten anywhere, basically. So you need a regulatory unlock and then you need a catalyst.

Right, and is this where the election came in for Kalshi?

TM: I think the election was, I think, enough of a catalyst to get this done because what we viewed is, first of all, election is one of the holy grails of prediction markets because it’s so clear how it could be useful. Everybody cares about elections and people really care about who’s going to win the election and who’s going to win the election really impacts people in a variety of different ways. And now it’s, I think, one of the biggest battles because we start working on the election market end of 2021, so working with policymakers, the regulators, then they banned us at the end of 2022, and we lost like I mean, a third of our team then. I think people kind of lost faith in this whole thing.

Lost faith, yeah.

TM: Yeah, it’s like, “Strategy is wrong and why are you focused on this?”, and all of that. And our response to that was, “We’re going to try again this year”, so we tried again in 2022 to 23, got banned again at the end of 23. And I think that was, I would say the most crucible moment of the company where we decided to sue our own regulators, so the the government, and we did that before it was actually cool or trendy to sue a regulator.

Right.

TM: Now everybody is suing regulators and the SEC left and right, but at the time it was very, very hard. And remember, Alfred [Lin] from Sequoia was on the board. Our board was supportive, but what they did say is in terms of patterns, this is definitely an anti-pattern. For a startup your size, suing your own government, that you generally die, the net result, you end up dying and there’s all these ways that they can hurt you. But oftentimes these companies, the thing that actually makes the company succeed is an anti-pattern, it’s something weird that ends up happening.

It makes me think of Uber, they had to operate in the gray and get — that was an anti-pattern — “We’re going to systemically exploit regulation loopholes in city after city, get passengers on our side to force the politicians to cater to us”. And to your point, in general, a bad idea, but sometimes it’s the only idea that’s going to pull it off, and a similar thing with suing the regulator, especially with the lawsuit goes in your favor, what, a month before the election? Is that when it came down?

TM: Yeah, exactly, that also just sometimes things go your way. Right.

But what’s important — I mean, this is a little bit different from Uber because Uber could have a path, they could scale and you can create a narrative that there’s going to be enough customers and then the laws were not clear. Ours actually, the laws were clear, we thought we were right on the law, but the government just did not abide by that.

Yep.

TM: We’re like, one on my co-founders is extremely, extremely stubborn and kind of obsessed about election markets and she’s like, “Okay, the law applies to companies, individuals, but it also applies to government, so we’re going to have to hold them accountable for this”. So we sued and all the things that the board members were worried about happened, like death by a thousand paper cuts and they don’t let you do this and this.

They’re going to take revenge on you in every way that they can.

TM: Everything you can possibly imagine starts happening. And you’re always thinking, is this because of the lawsuit or is this just because you never know, but it probably correlated.

But it happened, we really got the lift on being able to election on October 7th and that was, I think you have enough of demand, you have enough motivation in the customer, both the customers and the makers, liquidity providers to come around this market even in a short period of time and we had a few weeks to push it extremely hard to take prediction markets mainstream and that few weeks was like, it worked. It changed, I think that was the catalyst, the chain reaction started going.

How much volume came in those four weeks in the election market?

TM: It was like a billion-and-a-half to two billion.

And was that more than all the volume you’d had to date previously?

TM: Way, way more. We were doing $20 to $30 million a month before that. So it was just like 100x overnight, 50-to-100x overnight.

And so they all come in for the election and then does it turn out then a lot of that ends up staying around?

TM: Yeah, because now people are educated, they know what it is, they want to explore other things, the liquidity is also now started to percolate to other things and now there’s some math for us to work with. You can start optimizing the system, push liquidity in certain places, you have a reaction now. It’s not fully going parabolic, but you have something to play and you can add matches here and there and keep the reaction going. But that’s very different from death — stagnant, nothing happening, you bring someone in, they don’t find liquidity, you bring a liquidity provider, they don’t find customers, nothing is happening. So that was really kind of the initial thing.

But there was one thing that was really interesting, maybe one comment before we move forward, one learning — and Kalshi is an interesting business because we in took a lot of variance across time and when the variance went to the other side, so when in 2022 and 2023 we lost, the perception of leadership was like, “Oh, we did the wrong thing, execution was bad, strategy was bad, et cetera”, and when it went the right way, you kind of go from that to being an incredible operator.

And you’re like, “I’m doing the same thing all along”.

TM: You’re doing the same thing. And it’s funny because I give it always like the World Cup when the French team won the World Cup. Then four years later, they went to the last World Cup, which is 2022, and usually it’s been very consistent when the winner of the World Cup usually doesn’t make it past the playoffs every time.

Yeah, they don’t even make out a pool play.

TM: And the French team actually makes it to the final, not only do they make it to the final, they make it to penalties and they lose on penalties, which is literally a coin flip.

One of the greatest games of all time, it was amazing.

TM: The next day they call for the sacking of the coach. And sometimes this is kind of business, but I think the ability to take those risks is underappreciated because it enables you to play in environments that most people try to shy away from.

Yeah. Well, tell me about this, what is more important in a prediction market — you keep bringing up words like liquidity and market makers, things along those lines — what’s more important? Is it the retail investor, the volume, the number of traders, or is it folks that are putting in large amounts of money, not because they actually have a stake in the outcome, they’re trying to make an edge? You mentioned you were at Citadel, for example, probably the all time great example. Citadel doesn’t care what side of the bet it’s on, as long as it’s first to the bet and can make it on both sides, and they’re going to make fractions of a penny on every single trade, and they make money no matter what, it’s an amazing business. How does that balance work out in prediction markets and what’s the harder part of it to solve?

TM: I think it’s interesting. It’s chicken-and-the-egg, typical chicken-and-the-egg. So when a market has a lot of demand and there’s any other benchmarks of standards to price, the demand, the consumer side is more important, being able to attract consumers to the market because liquidity is a little bit easier.

But the more you go into the fringes, the harder the liquidity because there’s not like, “Will TikTok get banned?”, what are you going to base off your pricing, your initial pricing off of? It’s much harder to price that. You have to be much more independent in your thinking and the more you go into these types of markets, the more liquidity is actually the bottleneck and the more you have to figure out how to bring in enough information from diverse participants to basically price something.

Walk me through the mechanics here. “Is TikTok going to be banned?”, who creates that market? Who sets the parameters? Is that also a thing that Kalshi does or do people do it? How do the nuts and bolts of this work?

TM: Yeah, everything is centralized. So yeah, first market idea, it could be our team that is monitoring what’s trending, what’s top of people’s minds, what do people care about, and then list the market on that, or it could be user suggestions. Some users come and say, “Hey, we want to see this or that market”, and we put it in the pipeline.

Then I think there’s a bunch of regulatory stuff, make sure it’s not a market that could have perverse incentives. War, assassination, violence, those are things that are illegal for regulated exchange and we don’t do and we can talk a little about that, the distinction regulated and unregulated in a sec, but we’re regulated, so we cannot do any of these things. And then you have to have a clear set of rules and that’s hard because the rules need to be very precise.

The interesting thing though, it’s always been an issue in financial markets. The rules are always an issue. And I’ll give you two examples. Do you remember the scene in the Big Short where Michael Burry gets a credit default swap from Goldman, and then for a while Goldman was like, “Oh, the conditions are not met”, even though they were clearly met, so that’s one example of hard rules and financial markets, where there was a bit of a conflict of interest, so that was a different issue.

Two is when CME brought in butter futures, market participants started fighting each other and it was like, “No, this should count because milk is butter”, and then so what CME’s solution was like, “Okay, honestly, we don’t really care what butter is, but here’s the contract specs, they’re called event contracts because they’re a legal contract that says butter is going to be this level of saturation, this level of salt, whatever”, and so in this case, we have to have certainty, a legal contract that says, “Here’s how we’re going to settle this if the word goes in different ways”, and that’s a hard problem. You have to really think through all the potential edge cases and get smarter over time.

The beauty is now we have done so many of those that everything is kind of a template from something we’ve done in the past, and we’ve learned a lot from prior instances of those markets. And then after that, okay, you list the market and now you have to bring in the liquidity, and that’s kind of the key piece. The way to think about this is all of our markets go through direct listing, there’s no IPO process or anything like that. It’s actually, you just let it there, and generally what happens is that market participants in small size, they start battling a little bit, they start jousting, you see this curve in small size, like they’re testing the waters, “What does the market feel like this is?”, and there’s a little bit of negotiation via trading amongst all the market participants, and then it stabilizes. Then you feel like, “Okay, the market sort of oriented here”, and then once it stabilizes, liquidity starts going up over time because now people feel like, “Okay, it seems like this is where the market is”.

The variance is very bad for the market makers because they could just sort of get caught out. So once you have this small fry price discovery, it’s stable, then it’s safer to come in because it’s going to move, you might move a cent or two.

TM: Market makers like noise. So they like the small because they’re making money on spread, but they don’t like the sort of drastic shoots because that means that maybe they have—

They might have the wrong sign, yeah.

TM: Yeah, they missed some information, some news broke out that somebody is kind of capitalizing on and so that’s an interesting dynamic. That also matters for specific markets because election, what’s good about it is you know that you’re not going to get that all the way up until 5:00 PM after the polls close, so you can be safe in providing for a while until that. But in a market like will some news drop this year? That could drop any time of the day. So those are much harder to basically make for and for liquidity markets this tends to be a lot more of the bottleneck.

So how do you get liquidity into those markets? And where does that partnership with Susquehanna International Group, that was also in 2024, how important was that? Obviously being approved for the election market was the most important thing, but how important has it been to you to bring in institutional money as sort of a liquidity provider?

TM: It’s very important because I would say two things. Again, the chicken-and-the-egg, it’s like if Airbnb really wants to start building demand in a certain market, maybe buying or renting a few houses in bulk to get started is a good idea to show that there’s demand then get more hosts to start hosting and it’s a little bit the same here. It’s like you’re kind of getting a hotel maybe, but you’re getting a big market maker to provide liquidity a bunch of markets and liquidity begets liquidity. The dynamic that we just described, when you have more liquidity, it’s safer for you to come in and put liquidity. So if you come and see, “Hey, there’s a few other people here with a few tens of thousands already at the top of the book that is providing”, it’s easy for me to put another thousand on each side because I’m not the only one pricing.

You’re not causing it to skew all over the place just by coming in.

TM: Exactly. If you have an analysis that tells you it’s 55% and you’re going at it alone, you may not be certain, but if a bunch of other people also believe it’s 55% and they’re providing liquidity, you feel a bit better. And so having a first and then a second and third, it makes it easier to get the N+1 at every time, and so it’s very important.

So they helped us start equating, for example, the politics, the economics, some of the sports, some of the culture and that’s why it’s so important to have some of these providers because they are a bit the match that starts or the first domino that helps others basically feel confident in providing liquidity.

But do they come into these super obscure markets where it’s hard to get liquidity? Or is that where you have issues of Kalshi needs to come in itself as a market maker, but then you get people feeling like, “Oh, I’m betting against the house, this isn’t fair”, or whatever it might be.

TM: Yeah, it’s important to understand: Kalshi, the exchange itself never trades by law, by regulation we cannot. So there’s a separate company that’s an affiliate independently run that provides equity on the exchange, and that’s common structure with traditional stock market, traditional derivatives market, but they are treated literally like any other customer. So they have the same rights, same obligations, they don’t have access to any information that is sort of different than what a traditional customer would have access to, and this is why it helps.

And by the way, and I’ve said this publicly, it’s not profitable, so that’s not a place that makes money in the business and the reason they exist is exactly those markets. Sometimes if others don’t want to get started in some of those markets, but customers still want to trade and, “Will TikTok get banned?”, they could be the initial liquidity that helps others get started. ]

Really it’s a cost center. They’re a place, they’re a way to incentivize a bit like when Uber wins incentivizing new city or suburbs. Like yes, people need Uber in the suburbs, it’s not just in the middle of Manhattan and people need Uber and sometimes you need to provide it a bit of an incentive for people to go a little bit out of their way to get density there. And then after that, it could become organic as it scales and there’s more customers.

So just from an accounting perspective, would you say it’s a cost center? Is this above the line or below the line? Is this like a marketing expense almost?

TM: We think of it as like, yeah basically a marketing expense. I forgot or COGS, but basically it’s something that you put in like, okay, there’s markets that we make a lot of money or by that, I mean the market makers have enough of a pie to make money. And by the way, just to be clear, sports or election is some of our biggest markets.

Sports

Well, that’s what I was going to ask. There’s all these highfalutin ideals about prediction markets and how useful they are and instead of having to buy these baskets of goods or options or whatever, you could just bet on the event directly. However, does it turn out that people just want to bet on sports?

TM: I don’t think that’s the case. I mean, I think yes, a lot of people want to trade on sports, there is no question about that and we could talk about sports in a second a little bit more in depth, but there’s a lot of demand on the other things that just fluctuates in ebbs and flows.

I think back in 2024, 95% of our volume was in elections, on politics, because that was the most prescient, I think as we go into 2026, you’re going to see a lot around the midterms and it’s going to be like — I think politics is going to be a huge chunk. So you just need to have things that are topical. Our financials and crypto markets are also really big, so it’s not just that.

I think it’s a question actually, and I don’t think even question of demand, it’s a question of liquidity and recurrency. If you compare one market to one market, a lot of markets that are non-sports actually have as much value, but especially if you compare apples to apples, but there’s not enough of them. It’s a matter of us scaling our operations, being able to get those markets listed and then get enough liquidity on them, which is more difficult and so I don’t think that’s the case.

I think yes, I’m a believer in free markets. I’m a believer that, for example, for sports, this model is much better, there’s no house, you can be a price maker, you don’t have to be a price taker. There’s no house where the house always wins. It’s anybody’s game to basically trade against anybody and you’ve seen in the numbers, a much higher percentage of people basically win here. And it’s more social, more intrinsically interesting, it moves faster.

Is there a bit too where just there’s a lot of sports games every day again and again. So these are sort of short-lived markets on an individual basis versus, “X news is going to happen before Y”, or even in an election, that’s a one-time thing that’s years in the future?

TM: I think that’s a big part of it. I think that at the end of the day, there’s just a higher frequency of markets. That’s why people see this more per unit of time, more volume, per market, that’s not necessarily the case and that’s important in terms of what we’re talking about in terms of the demand.

I think the way to think about it is the pricing benefits, they don’t necessarily need to be uniform across all the sort of different markets. Some markets have pricing benefits to some people and some markets have pricing benefits to other people and it doesn’t need to be this thing where one market fits everybody all at once. But no, I think for us, applying a prediction market model for sports, just feels significantly superior than what’s traditionally the kind of business model. It seems it’s healthier, there’s less conflict of interest.

Not like screening out the sharps because they’re costing you too much money.

TM: Yeah, definitely. I mean, you can win as much as you can if you’re great, and there isn’t this incentive to make customers lose because we don’t make money out of somebody losing.

Right. You make money on your business models, you make money on transaction fees. Is there a bit where this high volume gives you a lot of transaction fees? I think it’s something like 80 some percent of your revenue is coming from these sports bets, but that is actually what’s enabling all the other parts that you’re more interested in, so it’s sort of working out on both sides.

TM: That tends to be true for a lot of businesses, that you have one piece that helps bootstrap or grow the other pieces. And you can see with Amazon, you can see that. I mean, a lot of companies and consumer companies, there’s one thing that’s working really well, and that one thing helps other things basically start working really well and in this case, for example, as you want to incentivize liquidity in some of the markets and questions that we really want answers to, those incentives comes from other places that are generating fees and other things.

Now, in terms of the incentive, the beauty here is where we incentivize is basically make it as clear as possible for customers what they’re trading and make them engage and make them essentially happy with the product, which I think is a healthier incentive long term than like, “Hey, I make more revenue if you lose more to me”, which I think is a more adverse incentive.

How do you deal though with your coming in sideways and, “Why do they get to be in all these sports markets, this sort of thing that’s been banned for a long time?” — how is this not gambling and why isn’t it regulated as gambling?

TM: I think there’s two things. I think one position, an important position to take is what is the underlying that you’re trading on and is there positive externalities?

People always have this idea of gambling. Okay, but let’s define gambling. What does that mean? Gambling, you could think of gambling as the thing, which is the gambling industry. You go to casinos and the business model is like revenue equals to customer’s losses and you’re rolling a dice and you’re trading on it and then there’s the verb which is like, “I’m putting some money to make money on something that I don’t control”, that’s actually a very widely understood definition of gambling. That definition applies to buying stock. It does, very narrowly in a very narrow sense. And in that action, actually, that action that we’re talking about, the speculative action, I think that sometimes when people use gambling it’s speculation, applies to a lot of activity that we see in the stock market. Whether it’s retail, individuals, also businesses and institutions.

So to me, it’s like the differentiator, if you want to take a principled line, is one, is there an underlying outcome that is actually useful where there’s positive externalities? In this case, whether some people can hedge on the thing, or they get informed by the price, or both, and that’s very different from trading on Brexit, or trading on the outcome of a game, which impacts a lot of people, a lot of people care about. It’s different from rolling a dice to speculate on it, which is an artificial risk that’s created versus a natural risk that exists.

And the second thing is the structure and the mechanics, which is very important. To me, gambling, why I think at the core, you cannot really call it stock market, even retail trading and stock market gambling, it’s because gambling is an industry that is basically, you go into a house, the house always win, their revenue—

Structured for the house to win.

TM: It’s structured for the house to win, it’s structured for the house’s revenue to equal to its customers’ losses. So obviously the incentive is to promote more losses from the customers, because that’s how you make money. Whereas this is not the case. This is the peer-to-peer, people are trading against each other.

Your structure is to increase volume.

TM: Exactly. Increase engagement and it’s very, very different, and I think it’s a much healthier mechanism, it’s a much healthier mode of engagement. And it looks and feels, and it is much closer to what you see in traditional financial markets, where price discovery is open and transparent.

Fees and Insider Trading

Do you feel tension though that by having transaction, by pricing on a per-transaction basis, you’re actually also a retardant on volume in the market, because more trades are going to cost people more money and this would be better if people could trade more freely?

TM: You mean the balance of fees?

Yeah.

TM: I think you have to balance it out, because if for example, we take the fees to zero, then we can not incentivize and provide liquidity in a bunch of places, and actually the volumes may actually go to zero.

So is that a super important lever for you, particularly with these institutional investors in terms of changing your free structure?

TM: Not just institutional, individuals, even more importantly. As you want to incentivize individuals to come in. And by the way, just to be clear, on sports and elections, the vast majority of our liquidity is individuals, it’s not these institutional people that you think. There’s a chunk from institutionals and a much bigger chunk from people that are individuals, that are peer-to-peer, people are trading against each other.

But I think that the more important thing is bringing more customers and more participation and more price discovery into these markets. And yes, fees generally, it’s always true, they add a little bit of friction to a marketplace, and that’s always true. But practically, when you take out fees, you cannot really operate the company, obviously.

All ways of making money in a purely liquid market are going to produce friction. Your estimation is that this particular one comes with the least bad trade-off, so that’s the one to do.

TM: If it’s structured the right way, and you have to have the right balance of fees, and you have to make sure that you have the right balance of incentives. And it’s a delicate balancing act, I would say but it’s a little bit like same question as Uber, could they have more transactions if they took out their fees? Probably not, honestly, because they wouldn’t be able to invest in R&D and make their product better and provide incentives for drivers, and probably total net sum of transactions would go down over time.

Yeah. You said earlier this month that you endorsed a prediction market ban on insider trading, because you already ban insider trading. Isn’t that counter to the whole idea that the idea of prediction markets is to surface information? Isn’t a lot of that disparate information that’s out there buried inside companies, or inside government, and shouldn’t we want insider trading, because then we get an early view of what’s going to happen?

TM: That’s a great question, and I’m glad you asked. So first a principle, so I think it’s important, and I think this gets lost a little bit in the conversation, that like any nascent industries there’s regulated and unregulated players and companies — and I made a post about this recently, which was a little bit of joke, but for every Robinhood.com, you have buy stocks on some offshore with crypto dotcom company.

And this is where your competitors come in terms of the ones that are offshore.

TM: And there are some competitors that unfortunately fall in that category. But it’s not even about a competition thing, it’s as we think about the impact on society and policymakers, I think it’s important to differentiate there are companies like us, and we’re not the only ones. There’s Robinhood, there’s Crypto.com, there’s Coinbase, they’re regulated. We have a bunch of laws that we abide by and we abide by US law and US regulations, the CFTC — the CFTC oversees us, and we have a number of things that we have to do by law.

So let’s just define the things that need to be done by law. We have to do KYC [Know Your Customer], we have to know who our customers are, get their social security, their name, their address, like a financial broker. We have to do due diligence on them, make sure there’s the source of funds for money laundering checks and sanctions and all of that and we have to run a comprehensive surveillance program, which is a bit like the New York Stock Exchange.

So think about the rules against insider trading and market inflation that you see in the New York Stock Exchange, ours are mimicked the same way, same rules, because we have to and we have the same enforcement mechanism, so you flag weird suspicious patterns. Usually when people commit fraud, they do weird things. You flag that, it goes to investigation, then you catch them and if we catch them doing inside trading, that’s a financial crime, that is illegal, that’s not allowed.

Now, there’s a question you’re asking that’s a bit more philosophical, or at a policy level, which is this the right thing?

What’s the point of prediction market? Is it the ultimate positive externality that we are surfacing knowledge that would not surface otherwise?

TM: So that’s the point of any market, any market does price discovery. Any financial market, at least to some extent, does price discoveries. It’s done on stocks, it’s done on interest rates, it’s done on credit, it’s done on currencies, and it’s done in our case on events, on the future, on the future forecasts.

But insider trading is banned in all of these markets, right? It’s banned in the stock market. And the reason and the principle line to take, I think there’s two reasons. One, and the way that we define it is you cannot trade on material non-public information, which means that you cannot trade on information that is not supposed to be public. If you work at the BLS, and there is rules in the BLS on the underlying, the national work, that you’re not supposed to release that information, trading it is a way to release it.

Yeah, so there’s already a law in place, you’re already violating it by insider trading.

TM: You’re violating the thing.

The second reason is fairness, there’s that reason for a stock market. The second reason trading is banned in the stock market is that if it’s not, then you won’t have a lot of liquidity. No one will feel safe being out there when somebody could come with illegally obtained, or information they have obtained that’s unobtainable for others to trade against them, they will be adversely selected and be hurt by that.

And so no, we are very much so the traditional market structure and traditional structure, because you don’t need to use that information to get enough price discovery. I think you can get a lot of price discovery without actually releasing the answer to something that you shouldn’t be releasing. And so, there’s a delicate balance like with all things, because you could argue that people should be trading on earnings ahead of earnings, but then how could we have a safe, fair stock market for anybody to find?

Do you feel like as a startup, as a relatively new market maker, which do you feel more strongly? Do you feel the incentive to, “We want our prediction markets to be consistently ahead of the curve, so people realize this is super useful?”, or do you feel that counterbalance, which is, “We don’t want people to feel like it’s unfair and so we need to protect market participants”, even if it reduces the quality of the overall takeaways that people can get from our product.

TM: I think the second one is very important, and I don’t think it takes away that much from prices currently. And the reason is because in a world where you’re letting insider trading and these things happen, which again, they’re not legal, these are not allowed, like current regs don’t allow for it. One, you could basically mess up with the underlying, like people now can release BLS data ahead of time, which is not a good thing. That’s just now messing up with a real — and you can extrapolate that to a variety of different examples. And then two, people will stop participating, because they believe that it’s not fair. And then I think if people stop participating over time, you’re not going to get a lot of the price discovery that you want to get.

Social Value

This is my last question, but do you ever step back and think about you have product market fit, and there can be very narrow things. Obviously, you go back to the initial example of the Trump bet in 2016, and how you should be able to bet on that directly. You were able to bet on that directly in 2024 and to widely written about, widely discussed, you talked about it, major company. There’s also this broader philosophical debate about a lot of young people in particular feeling somewhat left out of the economy, or feeling that the upside isn’t what they were promised, that if they put in hard work and do the nine-to-five, that they’ll be a millionaire by the time they retire. And so, now there’s like a, “Whatever, might as well speculate”, is there an aspect, is there something to that? That’s part of your product market fit? A certain sort of disillusionment and malaise in the world generally, or is that above your pay grade?

TM: I’ll give you some of my thoughts on that. I go back, similar to some of the questions that we had before. Look, I’ll say two things. Financial markets come with risk, and yes, there’s speculation at any type of financial markets. That argument that you just made could be made about options, could be made about crypto, could be made about really any mechanism.

Right. This isn’t a prediction market point.

TM: Yeah. But the important thing, and that’s going to go back to the regulatory piece, it can be managed appropriately. If you have the right safeguards and you actually put measures around customer protections, and you have federal government and regulators on top of you, the bad incentives in the system get drastically mitigated. So I think doing this on places where there is real customer protection and good incentives embedded into the system is much better than places, I’m assuming we all agree that offshore, which usually is where vast majority of this stuff goes, where sometimes you lose your money, you don’t even know where your money goes, or even in places where the incentives are messed up and they’re screwed. They actually want to promote more of that, I would say, dangerous type of behavior.

The second thing I think, and it’s honestly part of why we started Kalshi and it got me really excited is, if a lot of that energy is going to the stock market, not specifically stock market, options market and Wall Street, I call them the kind of Wall Street markets, I think there’s a little bit of a feeling generally that overall the game is rigged against people.

Yeah, the house is back.

TM: Yeah, right. A little bit, right? You feel that if you’re trading on stocks or options or some of the traditional stuff, how could you have more information than the large market makers, the large Wall Street banks and institutions, that are seeing everything way more than you do? They have 10x more, 100x more access to information than you do and there’s a little bit of elegance and beauty in Kalshi. We see it across the board. People that start this as a hobby and they do it full time and they read the news a lot, they care about the economy, they care about politics, they care about sometimes esoteric things like the weather and they study that every day, and it’s a bit of their home turf.

Yeah. You’re reducing the variables in a bet to just one variable, because the more variables there are, the bigger advantages the house has.

TM: I’m reducing the imbalance, there’s a level playing field aspect to prediction market, which is like — and I give this example, I think I told you about this last time, the best inflation forecaster on Kalshi is not one of the hedge funded institutions or sophisticated Wall Street guys, it’s a guy that lives in Kansas, never really traded the stock market, loves reading the news, very avid news reader and has just spent a lot of time thinking about how the economy progresses. And it’s pretty cool and pretty awesome this person can make a little bit of money on this passion and hobby of theirs and then also bring useful information to the markets for us to get informed. Our inflation forecast is the most accurate on the planet, so pretty much most of our forecasts are more accurate than any of the alternatives. But I think there’s just, in my opinion, it’s a much healthier place to be in than a place where the game is rigged against you.

Do you ever worry though, that as you get larger and the importance of having institutional money and to provide liquidity, all these sorts of things, will you lose that? Will you lose the sense that the little guy’s on the same playing field as the big guy? Or is it the simplicity of the market, either something happens or it doesn’t, give you confidence you can avoid becoming the house?

TM: I think simplicity and the fact that there’s a real fair value, like Brexit will happen or not. Whereas the stock market, it’s not just about, “What is the fair value of Apple?”, it’s, “Where are the mutual funds buying and who’s buying where?” and you have to have access to a much broader set of information to figure out the right price and that broader set of information is oftentimes inaccessible to the individual, to the person that may not. Whereas here, it doesn’t matter who’s buying what, either Brexit will happen or not, there’s a real intrinsic fair value. And if you’re smart about politics and you read a lot and you’re really interested in that, you can basically figure that out, independently of where people are buying.

And this is good for society?

TM: Definitely, I think this idea of getting smarter about a lot of these different topics and events is — and people could argue, are we getting insanely significantly stronger, smarter, or 20, 30% smarter? I would say even in 20, 30% case, it’s very, very important, very useful, because we can make decisions a little bit better, we can allocate resources a little bit better, and we can manage risks a little bit better. And that’s, I think, a very useful thing to have.

Tarek Mansour, it’s great to talk to you. I look forward to seeing how you progress.

TM: Thanks so much, Ben. Thanks for having me.

feed_name: Roger Wong - Design, UX, AI, Technology
title: Design Tools Are The New Design Deliverables
content:
Brand guidelines have always been a compromise. You document the rules—colors, typography, spacing, logo usage—and hope people follow them. They don't, or they follow the letter while missing the spirit. Every designer who's inherited a brand system knows the drift: assets that are technically on-brand but feel wrong, or interpretations that stretch "flexibility" past recognition.

Luke Wroblewski is pointing at something different:

Design projects used to end when "final" assets were sent over to a client. If more assets were needed, the client would work with the same designer again or use brand guidelines to guide the work of others. But with today's AI software development tools, there's a third option: custom tools that create assets on demand, with brand guidelines encoded directly in.

The key word is encoded. Not documented. Not explained in a PDF that someone skims once. Built into software that enforces the rules automatically.

Wroblewski again:

So instead of handing over static assets and static guidelines, designers can deliver custom software. Tools that let clients create their own on-brand assets whenever they need them.

That is a super interesting way of looking at it.

He built a proof of concept—the LukeW Character Maker—where an LLM rewrites user requests to align with brand style before the image model generates anything. The guidelines aren't a reference document; they're guardrails in the code.

This isn't purely theoretical. When Pentagram designed Performance.gov in 2024, they delivered a library of 1,500 AI-generated icons that any federal agency could use going forward. Paula Scher defended the approach by calling it "self-sustaining"—the deliverable wasn't a fixed set of illustrations but a system that could produce more:

The problem that's plagued government publishing is the inability to put together a program because of the interference of different people with different ideas. This solved that.

I think this is an interesting glimpse into the future. Brand guidelines might have software with them. I can even see a day where AI can generate new design system components based on guidelines.
